awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Automated Emotional Distress Severity Classification Using Speech Analytics and SFSS for SUD and OUD-Related ACE and Trauma
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will result from a focus on families with low socioeconomic status (SES), in whom adverse childhood experiences (ACE) and opioid use disorder (OUD) are common. Children of parents with OUD have higher incidences of ACE due to neglect, physical abuse, or domestic violence. ACE have life-long adverse consequences, including drug abuse, early disability, and death. By improving the timely and objective measurement of mental health issues in children and adolescents using innovative technology, the company aims to help providers and public funding sources, such as Medicaid, meet the triple aim of improving care, quality and experience at a lower cost. The analytic solutions are intended to help mental health professionals working with children and adolescents identify problems and emotional disorder severity early and efficiently, and track treatment progress and outcomes systematically. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project aims to develop a machine learning (ML) algorithm that detects clinically relevant emotional distress in speech samples from at-risk youth receiving mental health and family preservation services. Following preliminary work with two community behavioral health organizations that serve rural and urban families in Georgia, the company has an operational cloud-based digital health platform that integrates the collection of voice samples from minors with a validated youth mental health survey. In collaboration with a voice and speech signal processing expert at the Georgia Institute of Technology, early work has advanced two ML models that will be further developed and validated in the proposed project. In Aim 1, Symptoms and Functioning Severity Scale (SFSS) and voice data will be systematically collected by therapists using the company app at the point of care in a community-based sample of youth receiving mental health services. EMR clinical data will help categorize voice sample data to train, validate, and test the ML algorithms. In Aim 2, independent evaluators will observe and make redesign recommendations of the therapist training and implementation protocol. The deliverable is a stakeholder centered ML treatment outcome tracking platform for the behavioral healthcare system.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
In America, there are ongoing disparities in psychological treatment outcomes for at-risk youth in marginalized communities. This disparity has contributed to the significant increase of suicidal behavior for African American youth, 76%, between 2010 and 2017. The disparities in treatment outcomes are partly related to the lack of objective diagnostic technology to augment the services therapist provide at the point of care when it matters the most. Also, there is limited collaboration and sharing data between two key stakeholders: therapists from community behavioral health agencies and Utilization Managers from Medicaid Managed Care (MCO) payers.

Many community behavioral health organizations rely on a subjective evaluation by a counselor that is not licensed and has minimal experience. The service delivery model currently involves face-to-face therapy sessions followed by session notes for billing purposes; there is limited use of scientifically validated measurement of treatment progress to quantify treatment effectiveness. In many cases, there are no objective measurements (an assessment of the severity of the patient's condition) to determine the effectiveness of the services.

Due to the lack of objective patient condition measurement and experienced counselors, Medicaid Managed Care health plans are then significantly impacted by poor treatment outcomes, including unnecessary hospitalization; 9 to 13% of hospitalization being unnecessary is a significant pain identified by MCO?s. The core of the issue is the lack of care coordination between Medicaid Managed Care and therapists in identifying high-risk patients and diverting them from hospitalizations.

TQIntelligence addresses disparities in treatment, the lack of quantitative patient assessment, and health plan/therapist collaboration in the system of care for at-risk youth by developing a talk therapy software. Voice/Speech is a gateway to overall health; children and adolescents who experience psychiatric symptoms often lack the ability to express their distress. The therapeutic value of feeling heard and understood could significantly contribute to improved treatment outcomes. TQIntelligence?s software extracts voice biomarkers for emotional distress severity from a 45 to 60-second speech sample for children and adolescents with 75% accuracy.

TQI has built the technology that collects voice samples in youth receiving mental health services, at the point of care, using a software application (TQI App). The app and data collection process include the concurrent administration of a scientifically-validated, standardized distress survey (the Symptoms and Functioning Severity Scale, SFSS) that will serve to categorize voice sample data in distinct categories and the ACE (Adverse Childhood Experiences) survey. We are training a voice-based machine learning (ML) algorithm to stratify and identify high-risk patients.

Currently, there are ~10 companies who compete in the voice biomarker detection space as it pertains to healthcare. None have deployed a working model into production. Our primary differentiator is that our technology is built on clinical voice samples from the same patient population we are currently developing a solution. TQI is developing a one-of-a-kind proprietary clinical voice sample database and repository, representing marginalized communities (African American, Latino, and Caucasian within rural communities). Today, our database consists of a diverse set and size of voice samples essential for developing a more accurate algorithm(s) to detect and predict emotional disorder severity, and we are developing a proprietary voice biomarker to detect psychological distress and functional impairments in children and adolescents.

Alongside TQI?s voice biomarker and software, the web portal collaboration tool, Clarity AI, provides assessment and analytic tools to help providers and payers collaborate to reduce unnecessary hospitalizations. Our voice biomarker software helps Utilization Managers (UM) from Managed Care Organizations (MCO) and therapists collaborate by augmenting therapy with smart diagnostics, thus reducing the cost of unnecessary hospitalizations.

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project submitted by TQIntelligence (TQI, Atlanta, GA) was funded to develop over 9-months a machine learning (ML) algorithm that detects clinically relevant emotional distress in speech samples from at-risk youth receiving mental health and family preservation services. The algorithm we have developed to detect and predict emotional disorder severity is preliminary and will require additional data and funding to develop a more robust classification system. Developing a voice-based tool to categorize emotional distress severity has come with its challenges, as voice recognition technology has had a minimal use case in mental health. However, we have addressed these challenges and worked with two community behavioral health organizations that serve low income rural and urban families in Georgia, developing an operational Cloud-based digital health platform that integrates the collection of voice samples from minors with a validated youth mental health survey at the point-of-care.

TQI Clarity AI, once fully deployed and commercialized, will use innovation in voice recognition technology and artificial intelligence to detect and predict mental health disorder severity with the capability of providing feedback at the point of care for patients, families, and mental health providers. TQI?s innovation in digital health will also address the severe shortage of experienced mental health providers in low-resourced communities.


Last Modified: 08/25/2020
Modified by: Yared Alemu
